title: Passages from the English Note-books of Nathaniel Hawthorne. [Edited by S. H., i.e. Sophia Hawthorne.]
author: Hawthorne, Nathaniel
snippet: Thereis, howrever, a pervading sternness and grimness resulting from the dark grey granite, which is theuniversal building material both of the old and newedifices. Later in the forenoon we again walked out,and went along Argyle Street, and through the Trongate and the Saltmarket. The two latter were formerly the principal business streets, and, togetherwith High Street, the abode of the rich merchants andother great people of the town.

title: Friend Mac Donald
author: O'Rell, Max
snippet: Let us return down High Street as far as Argyle Street, the great arteryof Glasgow.

title: Sunny memories of foreign lands /
author: Stowe, Harriet Beecher
snippet: A crowd parting in the middle, through which we were conducted into a carriage, and loud cheers of welcome, sent athrob, as the voice of living Scotland. I looked out of the carriage, as we drove on, and saw, bythe light of a lantern, Argyle Street. It was past twelveo'clock when I found myself in a warm, cozy parlor, withfiiends, whom I have ever since been glad to remember.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: beats Con Philips, Anne Bellamy, and all former demireps, out and out. I think I supped once in her company, more than twenty years since, at Mat Lewis's in Argyle Street, where the company,  as the Duke says to Lucio, chanced to be ' fairer than honest.' * She was far from beautiful, if it be the same chif- fonne, but a smart saucy girl, with good eyes and dark hair, and the manners of a wild schoolboy. I am glad this accidental  meeting has escaped her memory — or, perhaps, is not accurately recorded in mine — for being a sort of French falconer, who hawk at all they see, I might have had a distinction  which I am far from desiring.

title: A Traveller's Notes, in Scotland, Belgium, Devonshire, the Channel Islands, the Mediterranean, France, Somersetshire, Cornwall, the Scilly Isles, Wilts, and Dorsetshire, in 1866. [By H. G.]
author: G., H.
snippet: Altogether there wasan air about the place which at once told of commercialwealth and activity on a very large scale, and contrastedmost strikingly with the quieter and more aristocratic grandeurof Edinburgh. I next made my way to Argyle Street, as fineand as busy a thoroughfare as Holborn; and thence to theTrongate, and up the High Street to the Cathedral. TheHigh Street is inhabited by the very lowest classes, and themany-storied houses, with the stairways leading to thedifferent flats, look more old-fashioned and more frowsy thanthose at Edinburgh.

title: Shamrock and thistle;
author: Optic, Oliver
snippet: " There is not much to be seen in Glasgow, and the city is of little importance to the tourist," said Dr. Winstock, as the procession of carriages turned into Argyle Street. " This is the principal street, and a ride of half an hour will give you a very good idea of the city, which is just like every other commercial town."

title: Curly. An actor's story, related by J. Coleman, etc
author: Coleman, John
snippet: Railways were now, more or less, all over Scotland, butthrough some prejudice, derived from the Dark Ages,there was still no communication between Glasgow andEdinburgh on Sunday. Sorely exercised in my mind asto how I was to get through in time to open at Aberdeen,I strolled down Argyle Street on Saturday morningtowards the railway station, when I perceived in thecrowd in the opposite direction, and o'ertopping everyonearound, a stately, white-bearded man, with the head and' front of Jove himself.'

title: And the Land Lay Still
author: Robertson, James
snippet: Croick wanted to go for a walk. They went along Argyle Street, up Buchanan Street past all the expensive shops,

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Buchanan Street, at the back of the Exchange, and running from Argyle Street, is the Regent Street of Glasgow, and is filled with elegant shops and warehouses. In St. Vincent Place, opposite the Western Club House, is an equestrian statue of Queen Victoria by Marochetti, erected to commemorate  her Majesty's visit to Glasgow in 1849.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Argyle Street is the principal street of Glasgow. At its eastern extremities it bears the names first of the Trongate, and afterwards of the Gallowgate.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol
author: Trench, Francis.
snippet: My expectations were highly raised as to thedue observance of the Sabbath in Scotland ; andon this, my first occasion of being able to judgeas an eve-witness, I can undoubtedly testifythat all my expectations were abundantly fulfilled. I looked up the long line formed by the Trongate and Argyle Street, just at the time when

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: I believe they were notpartners, but the law must look at these matters with differenteyes from those of a private individual. One of the shopwomenfrom Argyle Street, on being brought through to see Dan andJerry, identified Dan as a man who had been noticed loitering about the shop on the Saturday before the robbery, andwho had even entered the shop and made some triflingpurchase. So, by that girl's evidence, Dan was booked, whileJerry was as firmly limed by having been found with theproperty in his possession.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: In one of the pockets ofthese trousers we found a flat round brooch-case of imitationleather, worth perhaps sixpence, in which Dan had placedsome of his banjo strings. That case—fatal oversight—wasstamped inside with the address of the Argyle Street shop. As I read it I glanced at Dan, and saw his face change to aghastly and greenish hue.

title: A Traveller's Notes, in Scotland, Belgium, Devonshire, the Channel Islands, the Mediterranean, France, Somersetshire, Cornwall, the Scilly Isles, Wilts, and Dorsetshire, in 1866. [By H. G.]
author: G., H.
snippet: It was now time to makemy way back to the Railway Station, to return by the 4.15train to Edinburgh; and whilst resting on the sofa in thewaiting room, the following peculiarities of the City occurredto me:—The temperature is milder than at Edinburgh, thesea breezes coming from the West instead of the East; coalsare not conveyed about the City in sacks, but shot out fromthe coal wagons in bulk at the doors of the houses, andcarried in baskets to the cellars; the bakers' carts are all likesmall pianoforte vans; the hearses are ornamental cars, witha black angel at each corner of the canopy, under which thecoffin is placed, and the mourning coaches all have "dickies"behind them, like the old-fashioned "po-shays." The keeperof a spirit establishment in Argyle Street announces, that onSundays there is a prayer meeting and preaching in hishall; (query—spirits gratis)? The omnibuses are almost asnumerous as in London and the fares lower, as you can ridemore than a mile for a penny.
